channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Stick to Sanctions on Russia
item.description: The West must not sell out Ukraine to join Putin’s alliance against ISIS.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW FOXALL

item.title: U.S. Calls for Investigation of Shiite Deaths in Nigeria
item.description: Up to 1,000 members of a Shiite sect may have been killed in an attack Nigeria’s military blames on the sect.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Suspect in Xinjiang Mine Attack Spoke of Jihad, Chinese News Reports Say
item.description: The state-run news media released a televised confession of one man, and identified two other suspects in the assault.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: North Korea Sentences Canadian Pastor to Life in Prison
item.description: The Rev. Lim Hyeon-soo of suburban Toronto was the latest missionary convicted of subversive and “anti-state” crimes.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Japan’s Top Court Upholds Law Requiring Spouses to Share Surname
item.description: One justice said the law did not impose an undue burden on women partly because they could continue using their maiden names in their professional lives.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Mass Layoffs in China’s Coal Country Threaten Unrest
item.description: The test that the government faces in Hegang, a depressed coal town, is whether it can head off labor discontent in a slowing economy.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and YUFAN HUANG
item.media:credit: Li Qiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two workers at the Xingshan mine, affiliated with Longmay Group, in Hegang in Heilongjiang Province. In September, Longmay, the biggest coal company in northeastern China, announced that it planned to lay off 100,000.

item.title: Sinosphere: Case Against Civil Rights Lawyer Tests Free Speech in China
item.description: The specific legal implications surrounding the question of free speech are vexing many Chinese who are following Pu Zhiqiang’s plight.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Protesters displayed photographs of the human rights lawyer Pu Zhiqiang and signs demanding his release outside the Chinese government’s liaison office in Hong Kong.

item.title: U.S. Defense Chief to Confer With Iraqi Officials in Campaign Against ISIS
item.description: The defense secretary, Ashton B. Carter, was to meet with Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi and Khaled al-Obeidi, the Iraqi defense minister.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: John Kerry Visits Moscow to Prepare for Talks on Syria
item.description: Mr. Kerry met Tuesday with President Vladimir V. Putin in the Kremlin in talks intended to smooth differences over a planned round of Syria negotiations scheduled for Friday.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Muslim Parents on How They Talk to Their Children About Hatred and Extremism
item.description: A wave of recent attacks by extremists acting in the name of Islam has contributed to a rise in anti-Muslim speech.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER
item.media:credit: Ian Thomas Jansen-Lonnquist for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hafsa Salim waiting outside the Islamic Society of Boston Cultural Center in June for a shuttle to take her youngest daughter, Nura, to school.

item.title: Physicists in Europe Find Tantalizing Hints of a Mysterious New Particle
item.description: One possibility is that the particle — assuming it is real — is a heavier version of the Higgs boson, a particle that explains why other particles have mass.
item.dc:creator: DENNIS OVERBYE
item.media:description: Researchers at the Large Hadron Collider at CERN are smashing together protons to search for new particles and forces.

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Bodies Discovered Dumped in Southern State
item.description: The federal officials said eight of at least 19 bodies had been partly burned, and two more were found in pieces.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. Defense Chief Ashton Carter Prods Gulf States to Take Larger Role in ISIS Fight
item.description: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter, visiting Incirlik Air Base in southern Turkey, said he was “looking for the rest of the world to step up.”
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: News Analysis: Putin Gambit Over Syria Proves to Be Dual-Edged Sword
item.description: Vladimir V. Putin’s air campaign has helped him politically, but it has also come at great expense: in Russian lives, resources and a dangerous clash with Turkey.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Vladimir V. Putin, right, his foreign minister, Sergei Lavrov, left, and Secretary of State John Kerry met Tuesday night in Moscow.

item.title: Venezuelan Official Is Said to Be Charged in Drug Case in U.S. Court
item.description: Néstor Reverol, head of the country’s National Guard, and Edilberto Molina, a former official in its antidrug unit, are suspected of tipping off crime groups to investigations and raids.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY and WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Néstor Reverol, head of the Venezuelan National Guard, in 2010.

item.title: Hague Court Orders Retrial for 2 Aides to Milosevic
item.description: United Nations appeals judges ordered a new trial for two top aides of former President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, saying that they had been wrongfully acquitted in 2013.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: Speaker’s House Is Raided in Graft Inquiry
item.description: Eduardo Cunha is suspected of accepting at least $5 million in bribes linked to a sprawling kickback scandal at the state-run oil company, Petrobras.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Thai Woman Sentenced for Online Post Insulting Monarchy
item.description: A Thai military court on Tuesday sentenced a woman to seven years in jail for posting material on the Internet said to be insulting to the monarchy.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Open Source: Group Calls Israelis ‘Foreign Agents’ for Work on Behalf of Palestinians
item.description: A far-right Israeli group was accused of incitement for labeling leaders of four Israeli human rights organizations “foreign agents” in a widely viewed video.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Vote at Atomic Agency Officially Ends Inquiry Into Iran’s Nuclear Past
item.description: The nations controlling the International Atomic Energy Agency voted to end a decade-long effort to get Tehran to answer questions about its suspected nuclear weapons-related activities.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Yukiya Amano, director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, in Vienna on Tuesday.
